metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of flux observation matrix (No.14 eddy covariance system) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (2012)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.14 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 30 May to 21 September, 2012. The site (100.35310° E, 38.85867° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1570.23 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.6 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500) was 0.15 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Sensible heat flux (H) is a significant component of land surface water and energy balance determinations. There are several methods for measuring surface water and heat fluxes, such as eddy covariance (EC) and Bowen ratio systems. For large-scale H, remote sensing (RS)-based observations are useful. RS instruments themselves cannot directly measure H. Therefore, methods for validating RS inversion products are critical for using such products. Since the 1990s, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has been widely applied to measure sensible heat flux around the world, and it has also been used to validate RS estimations owing to the large scale of its measurements.
research objective: In this study, a weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model is proposed to convert EC-scale H to LAS-scale H. It involves path-weighting functions of EC and LAS source areas in both regression and area kriging stages.
challenges: However, methods of converting one H scale to another to validate RS products are still open for question. The method does not consider the path-weighting function in the EC- to LAS-scale kriging with the regression residue, which inevitably brought about a bias estimation.
methods: In the kernel area, 18 EC system sets were installed for the experiment, 17 of which were used in this study. Observations and footprints of the 17 EC and four LAS groups between 12:00 and 12:30 BST (Beijing Standard Time) were averaged to obtain a mean value when the atmosphere stability was under unstable conditions with high turbulent fluxes. By considering the wind direction, the wind speeds were decomposed into north and east components (WS), and then weighted averages were calculated with the corresponding EC and LAS footprint weights. After abstracting FVC, NDVI, LST, and WS with the footprint models, nine regression models were built for each of the periods based on the proposed multiple linear regression model. The four independent variables were also abstracted for the four LAS footprints. The residual part of LAS H is then estimated from the 17 EC H residuals by the above WATA kriging model.
dataset: Four groups of LAS (two sets in each group) were installed in 3 × 3 and 2 × 1 MODIS pixels. In the kernel area, 18 EC system sets were installed for the experiment, 17 of which were used in this study. There are also 17 automatic weather station sets (including a super-station) installed in the field. Nine observations (06/15, 06/24, 07/10, 08/02, 08/11, 08/18, 08/27, 09/03, and 09/12) made between June and September 2012 were selected for this study. Synchronous ASTER RS products at 12:15 BST were downloaded from the US—National Aeronautics and Space Administration and processed according to Zhou et al. [26] and Bastiaanssen et al. [27], including the Land Surface Temperature (LST) [26], Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), and Fractional Vegetation Cover (FVC) [27].
findings: Results show that WATA RK outperforms traditional methods in most cases, improving estimation accuracy. The method is considered to provide an efficient validation of RS H flux products.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Example.Answer: A method used to measure evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces involves the use of a flux observation matrix with eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as part of the HiWATER experiment in an oasis-desert area.

Example.Question: What is a potential dataset that illustrates the challenges of validating remote sensing products for sensible heat flux?
Example.Answer: A potential dataset includes observations from 18 EC system sets and four LAS groups used to validate remote sensing products for sensible heat flux, particularly using the weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model to convert EC-scale H to LAS-scale H.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a research approach to improving the estimation of soil and vegetation component temperatures in a strongly advective environment?
Example.Answer: An approach involves using high-resolution thermal camera observations to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures, which are then used as inputs to the TSEB model, allowing for better validation and separation of evaporation and transpiration in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area.

Comparison.Question: How do eddy covariance systems compare to large aperture scintillometers in terms of measuring sensible heat flux over heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems measure sensible heat flux by directly capturing turbulent fluxes at specific points and are used in detailed observations like those in the HiWATER experiment. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers provide path-averaged measurements of sensible heat flux over larger areas, which can be useful for validating remote sensing products. Both methods have their own scale and precision benefits, with eddy covariance systems offering more localized data and scintillometers covering broader areas.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing techniques between using eddy covariance systems and thermal cameras for estimating evapotranspiration?
Comparison.Answer: Eddy covariance systems process data by capturing high-frequency flux measurements to estimate evapotranspiration through turbulent fluxes of heat and water vapor, applying corrections such as coordinate rotation and frequency response adjustments. Thermal cameras, on the other hand, use thermal radiation data to derive soil and canopy temperatures, which are then used in models like the TSEB to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and total evapotranspiration. The thermal camera approach involves image classification and temperature conversion techniques, which differ from the flux-based calculations of eddy covariance systems.

Comparison.Question: How does the approach of combining stable isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements enhance the validation of evapotranspiration models compared to using eddy covariance data alone?
Comparison.Answer: Combining stable isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements provides a more detailed validation of evapotranspiration models by allowing for the separation of evaporation and transpiration components. While eddy covariance systems offer direct flux measurements, they do not differentiate between these two processes. Stable isotopes can trace water movement through ecosystems, offering additional insights into the specific contributions of evaporation and transpiration, thus refining model validation and improving the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of eddy covariance systems in conjunction with high-resolution thermal imaging cameras enhance the interpretation of evapotranspiration patterns in heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: Eddy covariance systems provide direct measurements of turbulent fluxes such as latent heat (LE) and sensible heat (H) over a landscape. When combined with high-resolution thermal imaging cameras, which capture soil and canopy component temperatures, researchers can better partition evapotranspiration (ET) into evaporation (E) and transpiration (T). This integrated approach allows for improved validation and understanding of ET patterns by leveraging ground-based thermal data to refine models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB), particularly in areas with mixed soil and vegetation cover.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in utilizing multiscale observations for upscaling eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert environments?
Interpretation.Answer: One of the main challenges in utilizing multiscale observations is the poor availability of data across different scales, which hinders progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes. Moreover, the heterogeneous nature of oasis-desert environments requires a hierarchically nested approach to capture the interactions between different landscape components. This involves coordinating data from various sources, such as eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing instruments, to effectively capture and interpret the complex eco-hydrological dynamics.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the incorporation of path-weighting functions in regression kriging models improve the interpretation of sensible heat flux data across different spatial scales?
Interpretation.Answer: Incorporating path-weighting functions in regression kriging models can enhance the interpretation of sensible heat flux (H) data by accurately converting measurements from smaller scales (e.g., eddy covariance systems) to larger scales (e.g., large aperture scintillometers). This method accounts for source area variability and improves the bias estimation associated with traditional methods. By considering the spatial distribution of flux source areas, researchers can achieve more reliable validation and interpretation of remote sensing H flux products, leading to a better understanding of land surface water and energy balance.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using remote sensing techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in measuring evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes using remote sensing techniques arise primarily due to the complexity of separating soil and vegetation components, the need for accurate component temperature measurements, and the limitations of current temperature separation approaches in arid regions. Additionally, errors in image classification during remote sensing can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature, further complicating accurate flux measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to upscale eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, and how does instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales aim to address this?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces is challenging due to the lack of multiscale observations, which are crucial for capturing the complexity of these processes across different spatial scales. Instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, as employed in experiments like HiWATER, aims to address this by providing multiscale and multidisciplinary data through a structured network of observations, including eddy covariance towers, remote sensing, and meteorological stations, thus enabling a more comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes of bias when converting eddy covariance scale sensible heat flux measurements to large aperture scintillometer scale for validating remote sensing products?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The bias in converting eddy covariance scale sensible heat flux measurements to large aperture scintillometer scale arises from not considering the path-weighting function in the kriging process. This oversight leads to inaccuracies because the regression model does not fully account for the spatial variability and source area differences between the EC and LAS measurements, resulting in biased estimations when validating remote sensing products.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of applying a two-source energy balance model on the estimation of evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying a two-source energy balance model, like the TSEB, can lead to more accurate estimates of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes. This is because the model incorporates surface heterogeneity and differentiates between soil and canopy components. As a result, it provides reliable estimates of latent heat flux and energy partitioning, especially under strongly advective conditions, improving the understanding and management of water resources.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of multiscale observation systems impact the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of multiscale observation systems, such as those implemented in the HiWATER experiment, enhances the understanding of eco-hydrological processes by providing comprehensive and multidisciplinary data across hierarchically nested scales. This approach captures complex interactions between oasis and desert systems, supporting the investigation of multiscale phenomena and improving the accuracy of models and the validation of remote sensing data in such heterogeneous environments.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a weighted area-to-area regression kriging model for scaling sensible heat flux measurements from EC to LAS scales?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a weighted area-to-area regression kriging model to scale sensible heat flux measurements from EC to LAS scales can improve the estimation accuracy of large-scale heat fluxes. This method addresses biases by considering path-weighting functions, leading to more reliable validation of remote sensing products. It enhances the utility of RS data in representing large-scale processes, potentially benefiting agricultural monitoring and climate studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of implementing a multiscale observation system for evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data through a hierarchically nested observation system, which includes instruments for capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it significant to develop and apply methods like WATA RK for converting eddy covariance-scale heat fluxes to large aperture scintillometer-scale heat fluxes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing methods like WATA RK is significant for improving the accuracy of remote sensing products by providing efficient validation techniques for sensible heat flux estimations. This approach addresses the challenge of converting heat flux measurements from one scale to another, which is critical for validating remote sensing inversion products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to process raw eddy covariance data for flux analysis in heterogeneous agricultural landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The raw eddy covariance data is processed through several steps including despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic virtual temperature correction, and WPL correction. Additionally, the processed 30-minute flux values undergo quality evaluation based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data is filtered for instrument errors, precipitation events, and low turbulence conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale observations integrated in eco-hydrological experiments to capture heterogeneous land surface processes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Multiscale observations are integrated using a hierarchically nested instrumentation setup, including eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing platforms. These instruments are strategically placed across various landscapes to capture diverse eco-hydrological processes. The integration also involves airborne remote sensing missions using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and microwave radiometers, complemented by synchronous ground measurements.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and data collection strategies enable the multiscale observation of evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: The multiscale observation of evapotranspiration is enabled by using a hierarchical instrumentation setup that includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network. These are complemented by hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the conversion of small-scale sensible heat flux measurements to larger scales for remote sensing validation?
Enablement.Answer: The conversion is enabled by using a weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model, which considers path-weighting functions of eddy covariance (EC) and large aperture scintillometer (LAS) source areas during regression and area kriging stages. This method effectively bridges the scale difference and improves the validation of remote sensing sensible heat flux products.

Expectation.Question: Why might the multiscale observation methods used in the HiWATER experiment face challenges in accurately capturing eco-hydrological processes over heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: The multiscale observation methods used in the HiWATER experiment could face challenges due to poor availability of multiscale observations and the complexity of capturing interactions between different landscape features such as oasis, desert, and irrigated agricultural areas. Additionally, classification errors, particularly in image-based methods, can lead to inaccuracies in estimating variables such as canopy temperature, which are critical for models like the TSEB model.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The eddy covariance system is highly effective in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, especially when combined with other instruments like large aperture scintillometers and automated meteorological stations. This is evident in the HiWATER experiment, where it was part of a comprehensive network designed to address the challenge of monitoring heterogeneous surfaces. The system's ability to measure turbulent fluxes at a high frequency (10 Hz) enhances its utility in detailed process understanding.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise when attempting to convert the scale of sensible heat flux measurements from eddy covariance to large aperture scintillometer scale?
Judgmental.Answer: Converting sensible heat flux measurements from eddy covariance to large aperture scintillometer scale presents challenges such as bias estimation due to not considering path-weighting functions and potential errors in the kriging process. The proposed weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model addresses these challenges by incorporating path-weighting functions in both regression and kriging stages, thereby improving estimation accuracy and providing efficient validation of remote sensing H flux products.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the role of multiscale datasets in advancing the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Multiscale datasets play a crucial role in advancing the understanding of eco-hydrological processes in oasis-desert systems by providing comprehensive and hierarchical data across different scales. The HiWATER experiment, for instance, successfully utilized such datasets, including flux observation matrices, remote sensing data, and ground measurements, to study interactions within oasis-desert systems. These datasets enable detailed process analysis and model validation, leading to better insights into complex eco-hydrological dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how remote sensing data is validated using ground-based measurements for sensible heat flux estimation.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing data for sensible heat flux estimation is validated using ground-based measurements by employing methods such as the weighted area-to-area regression kriging (WATA RK) model. This model converts eddy covariance-scale heat flux data to match the larger scale of the remote sensing observations, using path-weighting functions in both regression and area kriging stages. This allows for comparing and validating remote sensing products with ground measurements.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the potential of remote sensing technologies in validating surface flux measurements and address any limitations of these technologies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Remote sensing (RS) technologies, such as imaging spectrometers and thermal imagers, are essential for validating large-scale surface flux measurements like sensible heat flux (H). However, RS instruments cannot directly measure H, making it critical to develop methods for converting smaller-scale measurements to RS scales. Limitations include potential biases from path-weighting functions and image classification errors, which can affect the accuracy of RS-based estimations and validations.
